body_html:
@apaszke Thank you for your answer! Yes, we just iterate through local variables and call __str__ of them. Well, it looks like it isn't the real problem of crash.
Also inside debugger we iterate through all alive threads (returned by threading.enumerate()) and add some attributes to these objects. Does PyTorch do anything special with programs's threads? How do you think, can it lead to crashes in some cases?
body_text:
@apaszke Thank you for your answer! Yes, we just iterate through local variables and call __str__ of them. Well, it looks like it isn't the real problem of crash.
Also inside debugger we iterate through all alive threads (returned by threading.enumerate()) and add some attributes to these objects. Does PyTorch do anything special with programs's threads? How do you think, can it lead to crashes in some cases?
body:
@apaszke Thank you for your answer! Yes, we just iterate through local variables and call `__str__` of them. Well, it looks like it isn't the real problem of crash.
Also inside debugger we iterate through all alive threads (returned by `threading.enumerate()`) and add some attributes to these objects. Does PyTorch do anything special with programs's threads? How do you think, can it lead to crashes in some cases?
